results.title: Exploding Fist +  for ZX Spectrum 48/128/+2
results.creator_credit: Beam Software, Firebird Software and Telecomsoft
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette and cover in a plastic cassette case.
results.brief_description: Exploding Fist + [computer game]. Exploding Fist + is a side view beat ‘em up for up to three players. Players fight increasingly tougher opponents to rank as 10th Dan with a wide variety of karate kicks, punches, cartwheels and blocks. Once players have attained the rank of 10th Dan, they must then defend their title against more opponents. Players either score eight points or have the most before the bout ends. Points are scored by striking a fighter. The two highest scoring fighters progress to the next bout. If there is a tie, a replay bout will take place. After every two bouts, surviving players can play a bonus game where they throw ninja stars at demons hiding in a dark alley for additional points.

results.title: Emulation of Europe Ablaze for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
This single and multiplayer game covers the period 1939 to 1945 and contains three scenarios that depict strategic bombings in Europe during World War II.

Original game developed and published by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64 in 1985.

results.title: Doc the Destroyer for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Beam Software, Melbourne House, Geoff Evans and Paul Kidd
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover and manual booklet in a plastic cassette case
results.brief_description: Doc the Destroyer [computer game]. Doc the Destroyer is a side view, strategy arcade adventure in a post apocalyptic setting for one player. At the start of the game, players are given 60 points which they can distribute between five statistics Strength, Endurance, Intelligence, Luck and Charisma. As Doc, players are presented with various choices that determine your next action and some will throw the player into arcade styled combat.

results.title: Demon Stalkers for Commodore 64/128
results.creator_credit: Micro Forte Studios and Electronic Arts
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover, code wheel, warranty card & manual (paper booklet) in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
Demon Stalkers is an action RPG and editor/construction set game. It is similar to Atari’s Gauntlet. The player can choose either the hero, armed with throwing knives, or the heroine, armed with a crossbow who must travel through ninety-nine mazes before meeting the final demon. The game features different enemies as you progress through the mazes, with clues to progression built in. There is also a two-player co-operative mode. The in-built level editor uses pull-down menus and offers a high level of flexibility. As well as creating actual levels, the player can create an integrated storyline and game world, since the in-game text can also be edited.
The game shipped with a Magic Cipher consisting of three cardboard wheels that, when moved to the correct positions, revealed the passwords were needed to access some of the lower levels of the dungeon. Some of the vital text in the cipher is in a tone of blue that could not be photocopied at that point, making the cipher a basic anti-piracy measure.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/demon-stalkers/

Last accessed: 14/04/2021

Original game developed by Micro Forte Studios for Commodore 64 and 128, published in 1987 by Electronic Arts.

results.title: Emulation of Decisive Battles of the American Civil War, Vol. 3 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
The third volume of the Decisive Battles of the American Civil War series allows the player to reenact another six crucial battles of the American Civil War: Wilderness, Spotsylvania, Cold Harbor, Atlanta, Franklin, Nashville. Just as the first and second volume, this turn-based, hex-based wargame focuses on simulating the limited control, communication and “fog of war” of a 19th-century battlefield, providing a challenge to the player taking command of either North or South forces. Apart from single and two player gameplay option, an editor is also available, enabling the creation of own scenarios.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1988 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Decisive Battles of the American Civil War, Vol. 2 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
The second volume of the Decisive Battles of the American Civil War series allows the player to reenact another five crucial battles of the American Civil War: Gaines Mill, Stones River, Gettysburg, Chickamauga, Chattanooga. Just as the first volume, this turn-based, hex-based wargame focuses on simulating the limited control, communication and “fog of war” of a 19th-century battlefield, providing a challenge to the player taking command of either North or South forces. Apart from single and two player gameplay option, an editor is also available, enabling the creation of own scenarios.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1988 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Decisive Battles of the American Civil War Vol 1 for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Decisive Battles of the American Civil War, Vol. 1 lets you take the place of commanding generals in six battles of the American Civil War: first Bull Run, Shiloh, second Bull Run, Antietam, Fredericksburg, and Chancellorsville. In that role, players not only issue orders but take actions such as sleeping and determining their level of personal participation in the battle. The result is a fast-paced simulation (one hour per turn) of important moments in Civil War history. Victory is determined by a tally of casualties and controlled objectives. Two players may face-off in hot-seat mode, or a single player may face the computer or just observe the computer controlling both sides.

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1988 by Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Emulation of Classic Cave Adventure  for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
Classic Cave Adventure is a single player text adventure set in a cave. Text commands allow the player to move and interact with environment. Commands are rigid and set to actions like “Move”

Original game created for Commodore 64 by Matthew Hall and released into the public domain circa 1985. More info on Matt Hall’s games can be found at: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/bedroom-coders-matthew-hall-15-commodore-64-games-rescued-from-decaying-cassettes/

results.title: Emulation of Castle of Terror for Commodore 64
results.brief_description:
A single-player adventure game where the player is given a quest by an old man at the local tavern to rescue his daughter from the clutches of the local Count (a vampire), who resides in the nearby castle. Throughout the game, the player gathers items, which can then be manipulated to solve various puzzles.

Original game developed by Beam Software for Commodore 64, Published in 1984 by Melbourne House.

results.title: Emulation of Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific for Commodore 64 emulation
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation (wargame). In the game the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the pacific theater during World War II. In the six simulated conflicts the player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire. Included scenarios are Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid. The player can gives orders to the individual units and squadrons, which include naval vessels and land based aircraft. The computer then simulates how they perform their actions. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group
